item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Daughter of a Detained Chinese Rights Activist Speaks
item.description: Liu Ping’s daughter and her lawyer say Ms. Liu is in detention after years of activism; most recently, she called on Chinese officials to disclose their assets.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screenshot from a Sina Weibo account showing the rights activist Liu Ping with an umbrella that says "Citizen," and underneath it, "Freedom, Righteousness, Love."

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 14
item.description: The E.U.’s image; a military commander denies U.S. or NATO responsibility for Afghan deaths; journalists’ records seized; a soybean ruling; and controversy over a Banksy mural.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Houses destroyed during intensive airstrikes in eastern Afghanistan.

item.title: India Ink: Rural Upstarts Move In on Colonial Lackeys
item.description: India’s long-term economic success and the health of its middle class depend on how fast the hierarchies inherited from the colonial past break down.
item.dc:creator: By SAMBUDDHA MITRA MUSTAFI
item.media:description: A man speaking on a cellphone in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Feb. 2, 2012.

item.title: After Citizen Protests, Israel Approves Austerity Budget
item.description: A plan for higher taxes has prompted demonstrations reminiscent of those that rocked the country in 2011, when crowds protested the high cost of living.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israelis from the tourism industry gathered outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office on Monday to protest potential cuts.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Guatemala: Former Dictator in Hospital
item.description: Efraín Ríos Montt was taken to a military hospital on Monday after fainting while on his way to a court hearing, the Guatemalan prison authorities said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Leader to Visit White House
item.description: Myanmar’s reformist president, Thein Sein, will visit the White House next week, the first such trip by a Myanmar head of state in almost 47 years.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Former Police Official Detained
item.description: A former deputy police chief in Chongqing, Tang Jianhua, has been placed under detention for taking nearly $3 million in bribes, according to the online version of People’s Daily.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: General Says U.S. Not to Blame in Death of Afghan Civilians
item.description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. said that neither the United States nor NATO was at fault in the deaths of civilians after airstrikes in April.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Last month, people visited houses destroyed during intensive airstrikes in Kunar Province.

item.title: 2 Waiters Arrested in Killing of Malcolm X’s Grandson
item.description: The men taken into custody worked at a bar in Mexico City where Malcolm Shabazz was beaten during what a prosecutor called a dispute over an excessive bill.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Rodolfo Fernando Rios Garza, a prosecutor, left, said he saw no evidence that Malcolm Shabazz’s attackers knew his background.

item.title: The Lede: Video Appears to Show Syrian Rebel Mutilating a Soldier’s Corpse
item.description: Supporters of the Syrian government posted a graphic video to YouTube on Sunday that appeared to show a rebel commander cutting out the heart and liver of a government soldier and threatening members of the country’s Alawite religious minority.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: News Analysis: Pakistan Vote Revives Premier’s Rivalry With Army
item.description: Nawaz Sharif’s previous term as prime minister ended when he was deposed by the military, and his new tenure may depend on how he gets along with the generals.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Imran Khan’s party, which finished well behind Nawaz Sharif's party in the voting, protested in Islamabad, Pakistan, Monday.

item.title: Obama Dismisses New Benghazi Furor But Condemns I.R.S.
item.description: President Obama rejected criticism of his handling of the Libya attacks as “a sideshow.” On the scandal at the Internal Revenue Service, he said the practice of singling out certain groups was “outrageous.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: President Obama commented on Benghazi and the I.R.S. at a news conference with Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Deeper Blame for Benghazi
item.description: Lapses of security were negligible compared with errors that let terrorists thrive.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ETHAN CHORIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: It’s Too Soon to Declare Victory in Guatemalan Genocide
item.description: There is evidence that the current president, Otto Pérez Molina, may have been involved in the same mass killings for which Efraín Ríos Montt was convicted.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA SANFORD

item.title: Major Retailers Join Bangladesh Safety Plan
item.description: Under mounting pressure, several companies agreed to a landmark plan to help pay for safety improvements in Bangladesh’s garment factories.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: A rescue worker at the site where a factory complex collapsed on April 24. The death toll stood Monday at 1,127. Crews have almost completed clearing debris and searching for the victims.

item.title: Britain’s Conservatives Split Over European Union
item.description: A clamor for Britain to exit the European Union appeared to be spreading even as Prime Minister David Cameron met with President Obama in Washington.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: President Obama at a news conference with Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain.

item.title: Obama and Cameron Press Putin on Syria
item.description: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain have taken generally cautious and deliberate approaches to the Syrian conflict.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Syrian Army soldiers advanced Monday on the village of Western Dumayna, which is about five miles north of the rebel-held city of Qusayr.

item.title: Pakistani Leader Moves Quickly to Form Government
item.description: Nawaz Sharif signaled his choice for finance minister as vote projections showed his party was near a majority in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A supporter of Imran Khan’s party chanted against vote-rigging in Islamabad on Monday.

item.title: France Confirms Second Case of Virus Linked to SARS
item.description: The cases are being watched closely because the transmission occurred in a shared hospital room.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: El Alto Journal: A Colorful Bolivian Bastion, Floating Above It All
item.description: Open displays of wealth are often embraced in El Alto, an illustration of the city’s unusual mix of leftist uprisings and capitalist strivings.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A feature of El Alto, Bolivia, is its open-air market, with vendors by the thousands filling miles of city streets with myriad wares every Sunday and Thursday.

item.title: Mayor in Japan Says ‘Comfort Women’ Played a Useful Role
item.description: Toru Hashimoto’s view that so-called comfort women provided relief for Japanese soldiers “risking their lives” was swiftly condemned by lawmakers and human rights groups.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Israel Approval Near for Austerity Budget
item.description: A plan for higher taxes has prompted demonstrations reminiscent of those that rocked the country in 2011, when crowds protested the high cost of living.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israelis from the tourism industry gathered outside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office on Monday to protest potential cuts.

item.title: Germany Accuses Refugee of Being Somali Pirates’ Accountant
item.description: The suspect was the bookkeeper for a group that hijacked the German tanker the Marida Marguerite and its crew three years ago, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: In Bavaria, Family Values That Merkel Could Do Without
item.description: Germany’s Christian Social Union, the sister party of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union, is embroiled in a scandal that threatens her re-election chances.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel with Horst Seehofer, the leader of the Christian Social Union. Members have paid relatives as assistants, damaging the party’s image ahead of September elections.

item.title: Examining Pakistan’s Election
item.description: Declan Walsh, the Pakistan correspondent of The New York Times who was expelled from the country, reports on the results of the recent election and his personal experience.
